body.warn: SELinux is only supported on servers. Workstation support will happen in the future.
SELinux is only supported on ext2/3, XFS, and JFS. Other filesystems lack the complete extended attribute support. This should change in the future.
Users on the AMD64 must convert from a 2005.0 or newer profile.
body.impo: As always, keep a LiveCD at hand in case things go wrong.
body.p: First switch your profile to the SELinux profile for your architecture:
body.pre:
# rm -f /etc/make.profile
x86: # ln -sf /usr/portage/profiles/selinux/2005.1/x86 /etc/make.profile x86 Hardened (PIE-SSP): # ln -sf /usr/portage/profiles/selinux/2005.1/x86/hardened /etc/make.profile PPC: # ln -sf /usr/portage/profiles/selinux/2005.1/ppc /etc/make.profile SPARC: # ln -sf /usr/portage/profiles/selinux/2005.1/sparc64 /etc/make.profile AMD64: # ln -sf /usr/portage/profiles/selinux/2005.1/amd64 /etc/make.profile
body.impo: The SELinux profile has significanly fewer USE flags asserted than the default profile. Use emerge info to see if any use flags need to be reenabled in make.conf.
body.note: It is not necessary to add selinux to your USE flags in make.conf. The SELinux profile already does this for you.
You may encounter this message from portage: "!!! SELinux module not found. Please verify that it was installed." This is normal, and will be fixed later in the conversion process.

body.p: We will start by updating essential packages. First check which version of linux-headers is installed.
body.pre: # emerge -s linux-headers or if you have gentoolkit installed: # equery list -i linux-headers
body.p: If the linux-headers version is older than 2.4.20, newer headers must be merged.
If you have merged new headers, or you are unsure if your glibc was compiled with newer headers, you must recompile glibc.
body.impo: This is a critical operation. Glibc must be compiled with newer linux-headers, otherwise some operations will malfunction.
